captions.text:
Monogamy --the practice of mating with a single
individual for an extended period of time--isn't

that popular in the animal kingdom. Only about
3% of mammals are monogamous, and, although

95% of birds pair off (at least for one breeding
season), paternity tests have revealed that
the avian world is chock-full of cheaters.

The least loyal bird species might be the
superb fairywren: they form lifelong bonds

and, if you watched a pair of them from morning
'til night for an entire breeding season,

you'd think they were perfectly faithful.
But that's only because female fairywrens

cheat under cover of darkness. Using radio
transmitters to track their movements, researchers

discovered that fertile females make daily,
pre-dawn flights to other territories. These

trips only last about 15 minutes, but apparently
that's more than long enough-- DNA tests show

that just 25% of baby superb fairywrens are
their father's biological children.

So modern genetics might be deflating our
romantic notions about lovebirds, but from

a biological standpoint, social monogamy without
sexual monogamy--that is, pairing up with

one individual and then copulating with others
on the side--makes a lot more sense than absolute

sexual loyalty. For birds, pairing up is a
good strategy because their young require

a ton of care, so males increase their chances
of successful reproduction if they stick around

and lend a beak. On the other hand, putting
all of one's eggs in a single basket is a

risky proposition, so it also makes sense
for males to try and slip some of their genetic

material into a few other nests if they can.
Females, of course, can't have more than one

nest, but for their part they can try to sneak
in some variety.

Cheating might also help explain the otherwise
unexpected physical differences between males

and females in apparently monogamous species.
We've long had a solid explanation for male/female

dimorphism in explicitly non-monogamous species:
if a male plans to mate with many females,

he needs to win their affection and fend off
other suitors. Over thousands of generations,

the traits that help him successfully mate
can become more and more pronounced, even
if they serve absolutely no other purpose.

For example, male gorillas--who fight each
other for exclusive mating rights with the

females in their clan-- are much larger than
female gorillas, while male and female gibbons,
which are monogamous, are the same size.

Which brings us to our favorite primates,
homo sapiens. There are undeniable physical

differences between males and females--but
it's unclear whether they're pronounced enough

to suggest that our ancestors lived in harems
like gorillas or whether our differences stem

from a monogamous but adulterous society like
the superb fairywren's.

One thing is clear: among all the species
on Earth, monogamy is rare, and sexual monogamy
is rarer.

There is, however, at least one known example
of perfect, lifelong fidelity, and its name

is Diplozoon paradoxum. When two of these
young flatworms find each other, they literally

fuse together to form what looks like a single
organism, and this adultery-free union lasts

for their entire long and amorous lives...
which they spend sucking blood from fishgills.
A truly romantic attachment!

comments.author: Vee Rivaille

comments.text:
I guess it is actually logical that monogamy has evolved in humans. The 
entire point of mating is to increase the probability of the species' 
survival. For other animals, death comes too fast and in a plethora of 
ways. Hence, if you make as many offspring as possible, the probability of 
the species' survival is high. However, if the probability of death is not 
so high, then there is no need for a large number of offspring. This is why 
there are so many sperm cells in semen. Most of them will die for a variety 
of reasons. However, if the sperm cells could reach the ovum without any 
obstacles or fatal encounters, there would be no need for so many of them. 
Why waste your precious resources and time on something that will 
essentially go to waste? As you see, it's only logical.﻿
comments.author: Feynstein100

comments.text:
+Mike Blain
Huh. I never thought of it that way.
comments.author: Feynstein100

comments.text:
+Feynstein100 Actually, the high number of sperm in semen is roughly in 
proportion to the practice of infidelity within the species. The Splendid 
Wren (in this video) has about the highest known number of sperm cells. 
Most sperm are not for fertilizing, they are hunter-killers designed 
specifically to recognized sperm from other males. There are other species 
which make a second mating physically impossible, so males have no 
competition, and so have very low sperm count.
Humans have a fairly high count (but not nearly as high as the wren), 
indicating we are "occasionally" unfaithful. Who would have suspected that?

comments.author: Yump Bagle

comments.text:
I know I'm six days late to the discussion but this subject kinda 
interested me. I was doing a little bit of minute research, I found that 
children separated from their biological parents and placed for adoption 
deal with trauma, and the hypothetical adopting parents will most likely 
accept and connect with the child at a slow pace if they are able to 
connect at all. You argue that everyone, or most people, should adopt but 
should people who would be ill-equip to help an adopted child through that 
sort of inner struggle (through lack of willingness, ability, 
understanding, etc.) really adopt? One possible argument might be that this 
person, or couple, shouldn't have children at all, but realistically people 
who want children will procreate or adopt no matter what you argue. 


On another related note... On an equal plane, from one fellow human being 
to another, I would appreciate your take on this: I have always thought 
that if I where to have children I would probably have just one until I met 
this my partner. She and I are still far from children but I know she will 
want to have 2-3. My primary reasons for not wanting a large family is 
because I am not accustom to it (growing up it was my mother, sister, and 
I) and I don't like the idea of contributing to the human population issue. 
I think If we where to have one biological child and 1-2 adopted children I 
would view that as ideal and it would be the best way to get her on board 
with the it. My question: Do you think it would be wrong to have both a 
biological child and an adopted child because the adopted child may feel 
less loved than their sibling despite any efforts to prevent it? I plan to 
mention the idea to her but I always like to hear multiple opinions, thank 
you!

comments.text:
+Yump Bagle Too many humans? Well, maybe on poor countries. You think that 
a rich nation is overpopulated because their cities are full of people, but 
the ratio per ground isn't that big in difference to a poorer country.

I was interested in the discussion between you and Musashi Yao, and I 
partially approve his theory. 
Remember that in Nature there is selection and even between humans there is 
more selection: 
you are cultured and brought up by your somewhat wealthy parents (surely 
better than people who hunt for finding something to eat etc.), and if you 
bring up a new your offspring he will grow and adapt better than an adopted 
kid that will have difficulty to adapt to your society, meaning that you 
will only "destroy your genetic pool" carried by your parents lineage. 

When you say "Don't spread unnecessary genes" you are meaning that you 
should not procreate and spread your "superior" genes (not on racial level, 
but on adaptation, intelligence, etc) and spread genes of "inferior 
quality" (yes, at high possibility your adopted son will have his natural 
offspring) that will downgrade the genetic pool of humans, leading on great 
scale to less intelligent or more violent humans.

And saying that genetics don't influence the intelligence of a human being, 
that is half-false and half-true:
the adopted will carry the genes of their parents, which he will be more 
intelligent if he had parents with superior intelligence than viceverse 
with the same level of instruction.

Btw we have freedom of choice, you are free to do what you want.
Mainly because i'm studying science, I find interesting both the outcomes 
of "extreme adoption" and "total selfishness"

Be what It will be, do what you think is right to do.

comments.text:
Harem, as it was used in Arabic, refereed to the female section of a Muslim 
house.  It was also occupied by family members of the wife/wives, female 
members of his family and young children.  If you actually look at the 
Aribic word, it literally means "Forbidden/sacred place."

In modern English, the word has a slightly different meaning.  The word 
harem in English refers to a group of females who mate with a single male. 
 So from an Arabic stand point, it would be an odd use.  From an English 
stand point, it makes perfect sense.

comments.text:
+Monica Horton
I never said anything like we should not follow our instincts. lol yes, I 
know we are biological creatures and I know we are animals, but when I say 
animals, I mean all animals besides humans. I'm also just saying we should 
not limit our understanding of polygamy and monogamy to just the biological 
sense.

Anyways, I'm not an expert on the matter, but I can say I prefer living in 
this way. The world is so much more better for me. If you don't like the 
organized way of living we have now, you can always leave and go to the 
wild and unclothe yourself if you want to. The very fact that you don't 
walk around public naked is partly because of your social environment, is 
it not? However, after centuries of living in this way, I think our minds 
have already evolved in a way that makes clothing, shelter, coupling and  
interacting the way it is now. Similar to how our feet has become so soft 
because of footwear that it has become extremely difficult for us to walk 
barefoot.

I think I'll prefer monogamy. I feel like if I'll get a partner who wants 
polygamy, I think I'll be suffering in a way worse than "not following my 
instincts." If I'm not following my instincts now, whatever those insticts 
are, I think I'm perfectly fine with it, because my mind and body is 
telling me I only want a one on one relationship. I guess that's my 
instinct? I already like the way I'm living as a human. Plus, in a 
monogamous life, there is less danger for HIV and when you have children, 
there is less complexities involved.

In any case, if you want multiple wives/husbands, there are always people 
out there who want an open relationship so I guess if you want such a 
relationship, just look for people who agree with you and don't force 
people to accept your views, or else you'll hurt them. There are also 
cultures out there that accept it. Maybe it's time to move? Plus, if you 
want another partner, divorce makes that easily possible anyway. We don't 
practice polygamy but we do practice serial polygamy.

comments.text:

Took the words right out of my mouth. Religion isn't the cause of our

comments.author: Novumic

comments.text:
+mathe roland I don't think that was Novumic's point... He wasn't pointing 
out that monogamy wasn't religious at all, nor that religion is bad. The 
act of staying monogamus does relate to religion, but is not solely 
dependent on it. The institution of marriage as a concept has been around 
for a very long time, but the act of staying with one main spouse may have 
started beforehand. Biologically, it made sense because we had to take car 
of those who passed down our genetics. As time passed, we tended to stay in 
pairs because that was the environment we were raised in (though not 
always). This isn't to say cheating or poligamy are entirely based on our 
biology. In fact, religion comes in to some of this. Religions and beliefs 
are by far some of the most intricate social creations mankind has ever 
thought of, and by far the most diverse. Though each individual with 
beliefs may have variations, many people around the world agree on similar 
concepts, such as the existence of an afterlife, "good deeds" and "bad 
deeds", and an overall power. Undeniably, another concept is the 
institution of marriage. And this is where it gets complicated, because 
each religion and belief views it differently, and each individual in each 
religion or belief have their own agreements and disagreements with what 
the religion says about marriage. And of course each individual would (or 
wouldn't) raise their child or children and influence the religious views 
they had later in life. You may be wondering how not raising a child would 
influence them, so to boil it down the emotional discharge that the parent 
leaves behind may affect how the child views the other parent or figure 
that raises them. And with all the complicated factors of divorces, 
separation, and custody battles in today's society, it's easy to see why 
some people feel a little better staying married and not getting detailed 
about the beliefs or completely exclude them. Not to mention, if monogamy 
were solely based on religion, the marriage wouldn't be successful for 
atheists, but studies show that atheists have the lowest divorce rate. This 
could point to an ancestral influence from previous atheists who saw how 
religion affected the institution of marriage and decide to stay outside of 
the church. This disposition toward religions and beliefs could carry on as 
successful.

Wow we're such a great and wonderful moral species, the world became such a

By the way, we are literally the worst and most destructive species on the

last 250 million years, and it's solely due to human intervention. That's 
right, this is the *only* mass extinction event that is caused by a single 
species, and that species is human. You can feel warm and fuzzy about our 
morality all you want, the fact is that we are worse than mosquitoes, 
killer bees, HIV, and all the other horrific species you can think of 
combined. But yes, we're nice to our own tribes.

only ones that attached it to a complex social construct, but that doesn't 
make our altruism any better.

I'd say it's more likely to be the opposite: with monogamous females to 
polygamist males.  I once herd it put that sperm is cheap and eggs are 
expensive.  In other words, it is easier and quicker to make human sperm 
then it is to make human eggs.  Because of relatively long gestation 
periods, it doesn't make biological sense for a human female to have more 
then one mate.  However, males do not have to wait for 9 moths to spread 
their genes a second time.  Because males can breed faster, it makes sense 
for them to have multiple partners.

hasn't been a recorded case (that she has worked on) that mentioned prenup 
the reason being for a divorce. Useless info, sorry. For what I looked up, 
as of 2014 the divorce rate is now at 51%. Of those divorce couples 95% 
divorced without a prenup, 5% divorced with a prenup. With those numbers it 
is safe to say that having a prenuptial agreement doesn't play a roll nor 
contribute in divorce. That's where your comments listed above come into 
play. Your words of advice should be preached and followed, same as 
everyone else's advice of marriage and relationships. Awesome advice a lot 
of you guys have. But all in all, having a prenuptial agreement would not 
harm only help you in the event (heaven forbid) a divorce should happen.

comments.author: kilmorecombine0

comments.text:
+kilmorecombine0
I'm quoting myself:
"You don't seem to understand what I was trying to say. Otherwise you 
wouldn't press the exact opposite without also contributing a reason as to 
why it's so "smart and logical" (These by the way mean basically the same 
thing)"

Nowhere did I say I expected you to agree with me. I just expected you to 
present an actual argument instead of just saying:

"[...]it is no longer that way anymore. It's just not."

Yeaaaaah, that *seems pretty logical* to me.

Also, I never said that prenups caused the raise in divorce rates - I just 
said that it contributed to them.

Also, as I said, prenuptial agreements have a negative effect in that they 
enable couples with children to break off much easily, damaging young 
children's ideas of family values.

And no, I also did not say we have to go back to what was. In fact, I go 
against such a thing. If you can't break off a marriage, that's even more 
damaging for children and people alike - a drunk and aggressive or cheating 
parent is simply not a good partner. (Prime examples of people who can't 
let go of their ego.) These will convey worse messages to their children 
than an act of divorce ever would.

Instead we should correct along the way. We managed to get from one extreme 
to the other - from never being able to break off a marriage to it being 
too easy. Now we have to find the golden middle, where only those can break 
off their marriage whose marriage wouldn't work no matter how much effort 
they put into it.

Say, a gay man pushes himself and marries a woman, and he just can't get it 
up after a while, and the pressure put on himself while he's trying to 
change is making him start to break down. The only real solution is a 
divorce (and a possible remarry to another man) even if children are 
already involved.

But if someone wants to break up with their spouse because, say, the wife 
wants to try it with another man (or a threeway, or some similar kinky 
stuff)
Or if because a father doesn't spend enough time with his daughter for *some 
reason* and the mother - instead of asking what's wrong - starts yelling at 
him, they are planning a divorce... well, these are just not good enough 
reasons.

Married people need to talk about what's wrong, and divorcing needs to be 
harder than putting effort into talking and practicing empathy towards 
someone else.

And at this point, *not* having a prenuptial agreement helps. Because if 
this happens, the only way you will get your share of the money is through 
talking. While talking, you may actually fix a marriage without having to 
break up. Or if not, you'll have understood your partner's standpoint 
enough to feel a dull, bittersweet caring for em. Which in turn would make 
you want not to fuck them up and take their possessions like some vulture 
waiting for an animal to fall.

Of course this requires a better system enabled by the state - like a 
forced two months couple therapy before you could divorce (or something 
that took more than 5 minutes to conceive).

So yeah, prenuptial agreements are a dead end that'll cause more misery 
than they are worth. My standpoint for the future is a system that 
rejuvenates lost loves.

Go, marriage and actually taking the effort to understand the person you 
once fallen for!
